Non Markovian Quantum Walk on Fibre Loops Support Code
  • Home
Version
  • Home

Edit on GitHub

This is the API documentation for the code related to simulating a non-markovian quantum walk in fibre loops.

NMFibreWalk.NMFibreWalk — Module

An implementation of the non-markovian quantum walk in k-space with a discrete bath

source
NMFibreWalk.Diagonalization — Type
Diagonalization(H)
Diagonalization(k, params)

The result of diagonalizing the system hamiltonian.

source
NMFibreWalk.ExtendedModelParameters — Type
ExtendedModelParameters([keyword args])

The parameters required to simulate the model, agnostic of how they are arrived at. Instead of specifying the bath spectrum and coupling directly, these values are computed later on.

  • v::Float64: Intracell hopping.

  • u::Float64: Ratio of inter to intracell hopping.

  • spectral_density::OhmicSpectralDensity: The spectral density to use for the bath.

  • N::Int64: The number of bath modes.

  • discretization::BathDiscretization: The bath discretization method to use. See BathDiscretization.

  • normalize::Bool: Whether to normalize the spectra density. See discretize_bath.

  • sw_approximation::Bool: Whether the system should simulated in the Schrieffer-Wolff approximation.

  • ω_A::Float64: The energy of the $A$ site.

  • η0::Float64: The damping rate of the small loop.

  • η0_bath::Float64: The damping rate of the big loop.

  • η_coup::Float64: The damping rate due to the transmission line attached to the small loop.

  • δ::Float64: The hybridization amplitude.

source
NMFibreWalk.ModelParameters — Type

The parameters required to simulate the model, agnostic of how they are arrived at.

  • v::Float64: Intracell hopping.

  • u::Float64: Ratio of inter to intracell hopping.

  • ε::Vector{Float64}: Bath energy levels.

  • g::Vector{Float64}: Bath coupling strengths.

  • sw_approximation::Bool: Whether the system should simulated in the Schrieffer-Wolff approximation.

  • ω_A::Float64: Energy of the A site

  • η::Vector{Float64}: The damping rates.

  • ψ::Float64: The asymmetry phase for the g.

source
NMFibreWalk.WalkSolution — Type
WalkSolution(k, params[, m_0])

A structure holding the information for the dynamic solution of the quantum walk for a specific $k$ and with optional initial position m_0. Callable with a time parameter.

source
NMFibreWalk.WalkSolution — Method

(WalkSolution)(t)

The solution state at time $t$.

source

NMFibreWalk.hamiltonian — Method
hamiltonian(k, params)

hamiltonian(k, params)

NMFibreWalk.BathDiscretizations — Module

Functionality related to the discretization of the spectral density into energies and coupling strengths. See discretize_bath.

source
NMFibreWalk.BathDiscretizations.BathDiscretization — Type
BathDiscretization

An abstract type that defines how the bath is being discretized.

source
NMFibreWalk.BathDiscretizations.ExponentialBathDiscretization — Type
ExponentialBathDiscretization()

Discretize the bath with an exponential density of states $ρ_{f} = Δ^{-1} u^{- rac{ω}{Δ}}$.

source
NMFibreWalk.BathDiscretizations.LinearBathDiscretization — Type
LinearBathDiscretization(integral_method=true, simple_energies=false)

Discretize the bath with a constant density of states. The field integral_method controls whether the coupling strengths are computed using the integral of the spectral density or an approximation.

source
NMFibreWalk.BathDiscretizations.OhmicSpectralDensity — Type
OhmicSpectralDensity(ω_c, J, α)

An ohmic spectral density of the form $J(ω) = J rac{α+1}{ω_c^{α+1}} ω_c^α$. Calling an instance evaluates the spectral density.

source
NMFibreWalk.BathDiscretizations.discretization_name — Method
discretization_name(discretization)

Returns the name of the discretization.

source
NMFibreWalk.BathDiscretizations.discretize_bath — Function
discretize_bath(scheme, J, N[, normalize=true])

Discretize the bath using scheme according to the spectral density J into N energies and coupling strengths. Returns the energies $ϵ$ and coupling strengths $g$ as vectors. The coupling strengths can be optionally normalized so that $∑_j g_j^2 = 1$.

source
